ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is more a flourless torte than a course. Take it like a rich dessert after a fine meal and it'll go down easy.

A low-stress class for the opera aficionado. Great for the musician who hasn't thought much about libretti. When I took this class there were lots of perspectives: I'm a music major and besides me we had a major each in architecture, psych, music, math, theater studies, and biology, plus one English grad student.

There is no real point to this class, but you get to read a bunch of librettos/ their original sources, and discuss how they are made into operas. The only graded work is a final paper. I found the class entertaining and I enjoyed reading the librettos, so I'd recommend it if you like opera (or want to get exposed to it). Prof mcclatchy also takes the class to a rehearsal at the met for free, and a backstage tour

On the whole, I enjoyed this class. The reading list is great, and Professor McClatchy is super entertaining. You probably already know going into this class if you will enjoy it - it definitely requires a liking of opera, or at least an interest. Even when I hated the opera we were looking at (cough Gertrude Stein cough) I enjoyed class enough to make the reading worth it. My only complaint is that there is literally no guidance on the paper, which is rather harrowing/stressful. It wasn't very clear exactly what the professor was looking for. But, I enjoyed the opera I wrote about, and was definitely interested in learning more about it.
